metadata./Title: Application of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid cytomorphology in diagnosing Nocardia otitidiscaviarum: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Nocardiosis is a rare infectious disease, which is frequently underdiagnosed because of the distinct 
bacterial shape of the causative agent and its developmental history. The morphological analysis of bronchoalveolar 
lavage fluid can facilitate the detection of pathogenic bacteria by observing cellular–bacterial interactions.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation An immunocompetent 67-year-old male patient of Asian ethnicity developed a cough without apparent cause 20 days earlier. We initially discovered mycobacteria that appeared to be Nocardia in the cytomor phological examination of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, which was later determined to be Nocardia otitidiscaviarum 
through metagenomic next-generation sequencing and microbiological cultures. The patient was eventually diagnosed with Nocardia pneumonitis after other testing and clinical signs were considered. After anti-infective treatment, 
the patient improved and was discharged.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Several diagnostic approaches were used in this case, and the importance of cell morphology as an early 
screening method was emphasized for suspected Nocardia infection.
Keywords  Nocardia otitidiscaviarum, Nocardia, BALF, Morphological analysis
sections.Introduction:
Introduction
Nocardia , a filamentous actinomycete of the Corynebac terium order [1], is a Gram-positive, aerobic bacte ria that exhibits weak acid-fast staining properties. It is 
ubiquitous in soil, decaying plants, and diverse organic 
substrates. To date, over 120 bacterial species have been 
recognized in this genus [2]. Nocardia  is primarily con sidered an opportunistic pathogen; however, Nocardia  
infections affect both immunocompromised and immu nocompetent individuals, with approximately one-third 
of the cases reported in immunocompetent individu als [3]. Depending on the transmission mode, Nocardia  
infections can manifest diversely, including pulmonary, 
cutaneous, and neurological diseases [4]. Nocardia aster oids, Nocardia brasiliensis, Nocardia farcinica, Nocardia 
nova, and Nocardia otitidiscaviarum are commonly asso ciated with lung infections [5]. This case report presents Open Access

Case report
Approximately 20 days earlier, a 67-year-old man of Asian 
ethnicity developed a cough without sputum production 
or shortness of breath. Subsequently, he experienced a 
low-grade fever for 2 days, but the specific temperature 
was unknown. The patient reported no substantial medi cal history and denied any allergies. Upon admission, 
his vital signs were within normal limits. Chest imaging 
indicated inflammatory lesions, suggesting a pulmonary 
infection (Fig.  1), necessitating further assessment and 
management.
Blood tests and sputum samples were collected for 
pathogen examination on day 2 of hospitalization. The 
key hematological indices included a white blood cell 
count of 4.1 ×  109/L, neutrophils at 72.2%, and lympho cytes at 17.9%. Biochemical markers indicated a C-reac tive protein level of 3.2  mg/L and a 630  µg/L d-dimer. 
Microscopic sputum analysis did not detect acid-fast 
bacilli, and the culture
sections.Results:
results were negative for patho genic bacteria.
On day 4 of hospitalization, bronchoalveolar lav age fluid (BALF) was collected for a comprehensive 
examination. The cytological BALF analysis results were 
suggestive of Nocardia  infection. Subsequently, the 
metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) test 
detected Nocardia otitidiscaviarum (110,724) and Cryp tococcus neoformans (18). Moderate quantities of Nocar dia were successfully cultured from the BALF (Fig. 2).
On day 5 of hospitalization, further assessments con firmed a positive BALF galactomannan test and a nega tive cryptococcal antigen test. Taken together, the patient 
was diagnosed with Nocardia  pneumonia, specifically 
caused by Nocardia otitidiscaviarum. Consequently, anti microbial therapy, consisting of the oral administration of two tablets of compounded amiodarone three times daily 
for 7 days, was initiated.
On day 12 of hospitalization, the patient’s cough 
improved considerably, with fewer coughing episodes 
and no sputum. His body temperature was normal, and 
the patient reported no chest tightness or breathing dif ficulties. With symptom improvement, the patient was 
safely discharged under medical supervision to continue 
recovery (Fig. 3).
In this case, an immunocompetent older male patient 
was suspected of having a pulmonary infection. The cyto logical BALF analysis results were suggestive of Nocardia  
infection, and the mNGS test detected Nocardia otitidis caviarum  and Cryptococcus neoformans. Moderate quan tities of Nocardia  were successfully cultured from BALF. 
Further assessments confirmed a positive BALF galac tomannan test and a negative cryptococcal antigen test. 
Taken together, the patient was diagnosed with Nocar dia pneumonia, specifically caused by Nocardia otiti discaviarum . After symptomatic treatment, the patient 
improved and was discharged.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
The primary means for identifying Nocardia  involve 
traditional pathogen identification
sections.Methods:
methods, polymer ase chain reaction (PCR) analysis, and mNGS gene 
sequencing. However, traditional pathogen identifi cation poses challenges because inconsistent stain ing can overlook Nocardia . Weak acid-fast staining is 
used only for symptoms suggestive of Nocardia  infec tion. Additionally, slow Nocardia  growth, along with 
the difficulty in isolating, results in a low isolation rate. 
The aerobic cultivation of visible colonies at 37 °C typi cally requires 2–7  days [6 ]. In some instances, it may 
require 4–6 weeks [7 ]. The colonies are chalky colored 
and embedded in agar; however, the rapid proliferation 
of dominant bacteria can obscure the target colony,

leading to missed diagnoses. Furthermore, immuno suppressants can prolong the growth cycle of Nocar dia [8], making cultivation more challenging. Of note, 
the presence of antibiotic resistance and diabetes can 
worsen the prognosis of patients with this infection 
[9, 10], emphasizing the need for accurate and timely 
diagnosis.
Gene sequencing is the most accurate approach for the 
species-level identification of Nocardia . Researchers have 
evaluated the involvement of various genes, including 
16S rRNA, secA1, hsp65, gyrA, and rpoB [11], and the 
molecular identification of Nocardia  through 16S DNA 
sequencing is regarded as the gold standard [12]. How ever, polymerase chain reaction (PCR)-based detection 
necessitates designing specific primers or probes, which 
numerous laboratories have yet to undertake.
mNGS, also termed high-throughput sequencing tech nology, offers the advantages of high efficiency and wide 
coverage. Nevertheless, mNGS exhibits a significantly 
higher false-positive detection rate for pathogenic bacte ria compared with conventional detection methods [13], and the cost of mNGS remains high, causing challenges 
in achieving widespread adoption.
The morphological analysis of BALF facilitates identify ing diverse cell types, classifying nucleated cells, discrim inating parasites and crystalline species, and identifying 
bacteria or fungi, among other tangible components [14]. 
The morphological analysis of Nocardia  can determine 
the numerical count, proportional shifts, and structural 
hallmarks of various cell types and facilitate detecting 
pathogenic bacteria by observing cellular–bacterial inter actions. However, Nocardia  staining often fails to dis tinguish the bacteria from the surrounding background 
cells. Furthermore, morphological BALF analysis neces sitates a concentrated specimen because a concentrated 
and enriched smear substantially enhances the likelihood 
of detecting pathogenic bacteria.
Conclusion
We recommend combining morphological BALF 
analysis with Gram staining for microscopic examina tion to improve Nocardia  pneumonia detection. Weak

staining solution. F The general bacterial BALF culture suggested dry, chalky and embedded agar-growing Nocardia (yellow arrows) colonies

acid-fast staining should be used to confirm findings 
suggestive of Nocardia  infections. In positive cases, cli nicians should extend the culture time, observe chalky 
coloration, monitor colony growth, and isolate or 
purify the bacteria promptly. Where possible, mNGS 
should be conducted to shorten the detection time. 
The morphological analysis of BALF is simple, fast, and 
effective for initial screening and reduces missed and 
misdiagnosis.
